Neopterons with paralyzing poison stingers. They are quite fragile, so carefully take them down with your Slinger or poison to safely carve materials.
_EnemyFeatures: Neopterons with paralyzing poison stingers on their abdomens. Since Vespoids are attracted to light, hunters can use brightmoss to mark large monsters, which Vespoid will then attack and paralyze. To finish off a Vespoid without damaging its delicate materials, a hunter must avoid blunt trauma and use attacks that gradually drain its health. Vespoid fluids are useful for crafting with monster bones.

_EnemyExp: Fanged beasts with pink fur that prefer mild, damp climates. Generally, they don't form large packs and only live together in small numbers.
_EnemyFeatures: Fanged beasts with pink fur. Packs typically consist of females and juveniles. An adult male Congalala may occasionally be sighted within a pack, but these are non-social creatures that don't establish a chain of command. Beware their terrific flatulence, as they will use it to inflict stench on perceived threats.

_EnemyExp: Fanged beasts with snow-white pelts. Blango travel in packs with a Blangonga at the head, working together to eliminate intruders.
_EnemyFeatures: Fanged beasts with snow-white pelts. Blango generally travel in groups with a Blangonga leading them. As a pack, they work together efficiently to eliminate threats to their territory, responding instantly to their leader's commands.

_EnemyExp: Male Ceratonoth. They use their large spikes to disperse lightning into the ground and protect the females of their sizeable herds.
_EnemyFeatures: Male Ceratonoth, known for their large herds. During sandstorms, they use their large spikes to channel any lightning strikes. This process sometimes causes fulgurite to form on parts of their bodies. A male responds quickly when a large predator attacks and makes an effort to lead his herd to safety.

_EnemyExp: Female Ceratonoth. In a harsh climate where nourishment is difficult to come by, they are frequently targeted by predators.
_EnemyBossExp: Ceratonoth juveniles are treasured by their herds. Due to their arrival during the Plenty, the people of Kunafa view them as a good omen.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that move between habitats in response to environmental changes. When in danger, they use their head plating to fight back.
_EnemyBossExp: Juvenile Dalthydon. Their cranial plating hasn't fully hardened yet, and their pelts are a neutral color to avoid drawing attention.
_EnemyFeatures: Herbivores that live in herds and move between habitats in response to environmental changes. Dalthydon are bred as livestock and play an important role in human life. Although they are docile in general, when the herd is in danger, they assume a group defensive formation and use their evolved cranial plating as a weapon.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that are raised as livestock. In addition to providing wool and milk, they are also used for physical labor.
_EnemyBossExp: Juvenile Dalthydon. Their cranial plating hasn't fully hardened yet, and their pelts are a neutral color to avoid drawing attention.

_EnemyExp: Neopterons that use swarming tactics to contain and subdue prey, then dissolve it from the inside. Sonic bombs will disable their sensory organs.
_EnemyFeatures: Neopterons that inhabit the Windward Plains. They use their needle-like mouths to pour digestive juices into carrion to dissolve it into easily consumed fluids. Feeding makes them bloated and sluggish, so they have to rest on walls or ceilings. Their forelegs double as sensory organs that they use to assess their surroundings, but they are quite sensitive, so a loud noise is usually enough to immobilize a Bulaqchi.

_EnemyExp: Carnivores that work together to attack intruders using their powerful jaws. A clever hunter can turn them against larger monsters.
_EnemyFeatures: Carnivores that prowl the Windward Plains. Their distinct jaw is designed to grab prey and not let go, and they excel at working together to hunt and deal with intruders. It's not uncommon to see a pack of Talioth take on a bigger monster and win by sheer numbers; a clever hunter will take advantage of this and use Talioth to distract or weaken their main target.

_EnemyExp: Winged wyverns that vibrate their thoraxes to create a deafening roar. You can nab screamer pods from them using the Hook Slinger.
_EnemyFeatures: Winged wyverns that inhabit the Windward Plains. Rather than do their own hunting, they use their high vantage to scavenge carrion. Baunos take shelter to avoid the lightning during an Inclemency. When a little intimidation is called for, they vibrate their thorax feathers to create a deafening roar. You can get screamer pods from them with the Hook Slinger.

_EnemyExp: Leviathans with distinct snouts that live near water. Obtain bleeding pods by firing your Hook Slinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures: Leviathans with distinct snouts that live near water. If the water is deep enough, a Gajios will stay submerged with only the tip of its nose exposed, waiting for prey to wander by. You can obtain bleeding pods with the Hook Slinger—but not without a fight.

_EnemyExp: Leviathans with beautiful scales and blade-like protrusions. They primarily inhabit the Scarlet Forest, and hunt in highly organized packs.
_EnemyFeatures: Leviathans whose bodies are covered with beautiful scales and sharp blades. As a pack, they work together to surround prey, but since most Piragill are too timid to make the kill, they usually wait for an opening and lunge all at once. Don't underestimate them; on water, their speed is unmatched, and those blades will make mincemeat of a hunter that wanders too close.

_EnemyExp: Winged wyverns that are identifiable by the long, sharp horn on their heads. Obtain piercing pods by firing the Hook Slinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures: Winged wyverns that are identifiable by the long, sharp horn on their heads—which just so happen to make great Slinger ammo. Large as the Harpios may be, they never attack hunters, choosing instead to stay by the water and prey on fish. On occasions when large fish scare the smaller ones to the surface, you might even get to see a bona fide Harpios feeding frenzy.

_EnemyExp: Small carnivores that prowl Oilwell Basin, hunting in small packs. They have been known to engage larger monsters while feeding.
_EnemyFeatures: Carnivores that prowl Oilwell Basin. Their skulls have evolved in a way that lets them expand and contract the plating, and lunge at prey with hammer-like blows. They hunt Gelidron and keep their packs small. There have been accounts of Kranodath engaging larger monsters while feeding, where they cling to the enemy's skull and stun it with repeated head bashes.

_EnemyExp: Neopterons with well-developed tail stingers and forelegs. They surround prey in colonies, using their tails to inject a sleeping agent.
_EnemyFeatures: Neopterons that inhabit the Iceshard Cliffs. Comaqchi rarely move around, staying adhered to the walls most of the time in large colonies. Their forelegs are well adapted to striking, and they can use their well-developed tail stingers to inject a sleeping agent that make targets easier to prey upon.

_EnemyExp: Amphibians that have adapted to their dry, hot habitat by producing a protective slime. Their tasty flesh makes them a target of carnivores.
_EnemyFeatures: Amphibians commonly found in Oilwell Basin. Subcutaneous slime protects them from getting burned. Gelidron lay ambushes, waiting to snap up prey with their big, meaty tongues. Fine hairs on their digits, combined with sharp claws, allow them to climb straight up walls. Unfortunately for the Gelidron, their edible parts are delicious, putting them in high demand with carnivores in the wild...as well as in Azuz.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that live in herds in cold areas. They are targeted by predators as a source of sustenance where flora and fauna are scarce.
_EnemyBossExp: Herbivores that live primarily in cold regions. The larger alphas protect the herd, and can be harvested for paralytic Slinger ammo.
_EnemyFeatures: Herbivores that live primarily in cold regions. Rafma form herds with a large alpha at the head. When threatened, the alpha discharges static energy stored in its horn to shock foes and defend the herd. This horn can also be targeted with the Hook Slinger to get paralytic ammo. Rafma have been sighted moving along dizzyingly steep cliffsides, to the wonderment of observers.

_EnemyExp: Bird wyverns with sharp bristles on their heads. Obtain Slinger ammo that is effective at creating wounds by firing your Hook Slinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures: Bird wyverns that live in herds at the heart of the Ruins of Wyveria. Porkeplumes are extremely timid and will protect themselves against threats by puffing out the bristles on their heads. If the situation escalates, a member of the herd will slam into the foe with its bristles, giving the other members a window to escape. The head bristles can be used as bleeding pods for the Slinger.

_EnemyExp: Newly-hatched Nerscylla larvae. They form colonies in the bodies of devoured prey, nests, and other hidey-holes, and react as a group when provoked.
_EnemyFeatures: The larval form of a temnoceran that inhabits the Iceshard Cliffs. At this stage, they cannot use webbing or status ailments like adult Nerscylla, but these little fellows like to gang up, surround prey, and then pounce all at once.

_EnemyExp: Artificial wyverns created by an ancient civilization. They hatch from small cocoons and travel in packs, attacking with sharp claws.
_EnemyFeatures: Artificial wyverns created by an ancient civilization. They dash through the Ruins of Wyveria in search of Wyvern Milk, their source of energy. Unlike the original Seikret, the Guardian types are aggressive and have sharp, dangerous claws on their unique forelegs. They generally travel in packs of two or three, but if threatened, they may call for more help and try to surround the adversary.

_EnemyExp: Toads containing a paralytic gas. Hitting them will release the gas, which is powerful enough to stop large monsters in their tracks.
_FirstCapture: Toads that contain a powerful, paralytic gas which they can use as a defensive measure to stop threats in their tracks.
_Memo: Toads containing a paralytic gas that are usually found by the water. They are sensitive to force and will release the gas as a defensive measure; it's powerful enough to stop hunters and large monsters in their tracks, which buys the Paratoad time to escape. Hunters can use this behavior to direct the gas at a desired target and gain the upper hand.

_EnemyExp: When struck, Nitrotoads release a spray of volatile liquid that detonates with enough power to stagger even large monsters.
_FirstCapture: A toad that stores an explosive liquid within its body. The explosions it produces are so strong they even make larger monsters flinch.
_Memo: Toads that store an explosive liquid within their bodies. Any physical stimulus causes them to spray this liquid and flee. Once the liquid contacts the air, it detonates, wreaking havoc. Though these creatures prefer to live in environments abounding in combustible materials like coal, their diet actually consists mostly of insects and crustaceans. It is yet unknown what causes them to produce the explosive liquid.

_EnemyExp: Toads that store sleeping gas in their bodies. A shock will cause them to spray the gas, which is potent enough to affect monsters.
_FirstCapture: Toads that store a potent gas in their bodies that can put monsters to sleep.
_Memo: Toads that store sleeping gas in their bodies. A shock will cause them to spray the gas, putting the enemy to sleep while they escape. The gas is so potent that it affects hunters and even large monsters. You may be able to gain the upper hand if you use this to your advantage and direct the gas at a monster.

_EnemyExp: Insects that carry restorative nectar. A light impact causes the nectar to scatter, producing a continual healing effect.
_FirstCapture: Insects that gather restorative nectar from Vitalilies and store it, with more or less the same properties, in their abdomens.
_Memo: Insects that gather restorative nectar from Vitalilies and store it in their abdomens. While the flowers and nectar have similar properties, the latter can be scattered in large quantities to produce a lingering, continual healing effect. There's a rise in the Vigorwasp population during the Plenty, when Vitalilies flourish.

_EnemyExp: Large wasps that carry more nectar at a higher concentration. A light impact scatters the nectar, producing a continual healing effect.
_FirstCapture: Large wasps that carry more nectar at a higher concentration. Frequently seen during the Plenty.
_Memo: Large wasps that carry more nectar at a higher concentration. This boosts the range and potency of the nectar's restorative effects. They are most prevalent during the Plenty, when the Vigorwasps have learned the nectar will be more plentiful. They are sometimes sighted in groups.

_EnemyExp: Insects that store nectar. An impact will cause them to release it, providing immediate health recovery and relief from status ailments.
_FirstCapture: Insects that store nectar in their abdomens with restorative, detoxifying, and deodorizing properties.
_Memo: Insects that store nectar in their abdomens with restorative, detoxifying, and deodorizing properties. Since the effects are different from a Vigorwasp's, it is believed that this species collects ingredients from medicinal plants other than Vitalilies. However, based on ongoing research, it has been found that enzymes in their bodies could also play a role.

_EnemyExp: Insects that flash when struck. The larger their colony, the brighter they shine. They can be used to blind large monsters.
_FirstCapture: Insects that flash when struck. Alone, their light is faint, but in colonies they shine more intensely.
_Memo: Insects that flash when struck. Usually, they live solitary existences with too faint a flicker to even notice. In caves or the dark of night, they form colonies where their light is more intense; striking them causes them to shine even brighter. On hunts, they can be used like flash bombs to blind and disorient monsters.

_EnemyExp: Insects that habitually roll up monster dung. The dung pods are well compacted and can be used as Slinger ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects that habitually roll up monster dung: nature's diligent decomposers. The dung pods can be used as Slinger ammo.
_Memo: Insects that habitually roll up monster dung. They bring it back to their underground nests not just for food, but to lay eggs on and feed their larvae. They're the faces of feces across the land: nature's diligent decomposers. The compacted dung pods formed by their efforts can be used as Slinger ammo. It's foul enough to send even large monsters running for fresh air—a useful trick when you're outnumbered.

_EnemyExp: An insect that rolls explosive rocks and brings them back to its nest. These rocks can be used as Slinger ammo.
_FirstCapture: An insect that rolls explosive rocks and brings them back to its nest. These rocks can be used as Slinger ammo.
_Memo: Beetles that roll around explosive rocks. Because both these rocks and their habitat are extremely hot, their bodies have evolved to withstand heat. It's yet unclear what they do with the rocks once they get back to their nests, but some theorize that they are fed to the beetles' young.

_EnemyExp: Beetles that gather up snowballs and roll them back to their nests. The snowballs can be used as Slinger frostburst ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects that roll balls of snow until they harden. These ice balls can be used as Slinger ammo.
_Memo: Beetles that gather up snow. Their snowballs can be used as Frostburst Ammo. Due to their ecology, Icebeetles are limited to cold habitats and are more tolerant of cold than other insects. No one knows why they roll their snowballs back to their nests. Some theorize it's to grow the organic matter they feed on, while others think it could be related to reproductive behavior.

_EnemyExp: Insects that wear healing herbs like cloaks, producing a restorative nectar that can be collected from them using the Hook Slinger.
_FirstCapture: Insects that wear healing herbs like cloaks. The cloak serves a double purpose: to store nutrients and to defend against predators.
_Memo: Insects that wear healing herbs like cloaks, initiating a fermentation process that creates a nectar with similar restorative properties. Collecting the cloak by hand or with the Hook Slinger will restore health. The cloak stores nutrients but can be shed in a pinch as a distraction to defend against predators.

_EnemyExp: Insects that hoard honey with heat-relieving properties in the casing on their backs. They ferment plants with cooling components.
_FirstCapture: An insect that wraps itself in a case of plant matter. The case has a mucus that protects it from high temperatures.
_Memo: Insects that live in extremely hot environments. They wrap themselves in a case of plant matter—much like their mantle bug brethren—but the plants they use have cooling properties, allowing them to withstand heat. They are able to survive without the casing by burrowing underground.

_EnemyExp: Insects that hoard honey with cold-relieving properties in the casing on their backs. They ferment plants with heating components.
_FirstCapture: An insect that wraps itself in a case of plant matter. The case has a mucus that protects it from low temperatures.
_Memo: Insects that live in extremely cold environments. They wrap themselves in plant matter—much like their mantle bug brethren—but they use plants with heating properties, such as hot peppers, to mitigate the cold. They can live on the surface thanks to this, but if uncloaked they must burrow underground to survive.

_EnemyExp: Insects that thrive in rotting wood and soil. Highly nutritious, they can be consumed to increase stamina and halve its depletion rate.
_FirstCapture: Insects that thrive in rotting wood and soil. Even monsters consume them because of their high nutritional value.
_Memo: Insects that thrive in rotting wood and soil due to their diet of plants and rotting leaves. Consuming them will increase stamina and halve its depletion rate. Their high nutritional value makes them a common snack for some monsters.

_EnemyExp: Nocturnal hornets that use a luminous organ to warn foes before attacking with their stingers— even large monsters aren't safe.
_FirstCapture: Nocturnal, territorial hornets that use a luminous organ to light up targets before attacking with poison stingers.
_Memo: Nocturnal hornets with strong defensive instincts. When they sense danger, they use a luminous organ to illuminate the area to check for threats, if one is spotted, they attack relentlessly with their poisonous stingers. Unlike other endemic life, Dark Hornets will readily attack large monsters that disturb their nests. Their diet also doesn't stimulate honey production, so hunters are better off steering clear.

_EnemyExp: A colony of Thunderbugs galvanized by sandstorm lightning. A population this dense can stop even large monsters in their tracks.
_FirstCapture: A large colony of Thunderbugs that have been vitalized by the sandstorm's lightning, resulting in a dense population.
_Memo: A large colony of Thunderbugs that reproduced rapidly as a result of the sandstorm lightning. A population this dense can produce enough current to stop even large monsters in their tracks. Since Thunderbugs are the fuel behind shock traps, there's merit to trying to lead large monsters into the colony as a way to gain the upper hand.

_EnemyExp: Insects that cling firmly to walls and other surfaces. Latching on to them with the Slinger can help you traverse terrain and evade attacks.
_FirstCapture: Insects with robust shells that can withstand lesser impacts. They make great latching points for the Slinger.
_Memo: Insects with robust shells that can withstand most lesser impacts. They cling firmly to walls and other surfaces, making them excellent latching points for the Slinger, whether it's to get around or simply to hang out indefinitely. However, a Wedge Beetle in flight can only bear the weight for a limited time, so it's best to latch on briefly to gain some height.

_EnemyExp: Insects that store electricity. Found near electrical sources, they can be used to make tools like shock traps and Thunder Ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects capable of discharging small amounts of electricity. They are drawn to electrical sources, which enhance them on contact.
_Memo: Insects capable of discharging small amounts of electricity. They are drawn to electrical sources, particularly the fulgurite formed by lightning strikes. Thunderbug materials can be used to craft many useful tools such as shock traps and Thunder Ammo.

_EnemyExp: Insects with apparatuses capable of producing strong bursts of light. Their materials are used in Slinger flash pods.
_FirstCapture: Insects that emit strong, involuntary bursts of light in response to external factors.
_Memo: Insects that emit strong bursts of light in response to external factors. It was long believed that blunt trauma or death were the triggers, but this theory has been rejected. It is now thought that some constituent element of their body fluid vaporizes and produces the flash. In any case, their materials are highly prized for their utility in items like Slinger flash pods.

_EnemyExp: Insects said to live for a thousand years. Their extracts can be combined with other items to create powders with their supportive properties.
_FirstCapture: Insects that live a very long time— a thousand years, by some accounts, although no such specimens have been discovered.
_Memo: Insects that are claimed by some tomes and oral histories to live for a thousand years. No such specimens have been discovered, but studies of the Godbug's tissue prove that they do enjoy significant longevity. Their body fluids have diffusive properties that can be combined with other items to create powders with the same attributes.

_EnemyExp: Insects whose bitter extracts promote natural healing and can be combined into a variety of useful medicines and items.
_FirstCapture: Insects whose bitter extracts promote natural healing, disinfect wounds, and more, making them a valuable material.
_Memo: Insects whose bitter extracts are used for a wide variety of medicinal purposes. In addition to promoting natural healing, disinfecting, and mitigating poisons, they also boost the efficacy of other medicines, making them highly useful. That said, by themselves they have little effect and taste extremely bitter, so it's best to consider them an ingredient, not a solution in their own right.

_EnemyExp: Forest ants that form ranks and carry leaves with medicinal properties, which can be collected to make healing items.
_FirstCapture: An ant that gathers leaves in droves. The leaves are brought to its nest and used to cultivate the fungi it eats.
_Memo: Forest ants known for forming ranks and carrying leaves. Their sharp mandibles consist of a sharp edge for cutting and a separate apparatus for bending the leaves back behind their heads for easy carrying. Leaflugger Ants use these leaves as substrates to grow fungi, their primary sustenance. As it turns out, the leaves also have medicinal properties, making them useful to hunters.

_EnemyExp: Herding monsters that mostly inhabit the savannah. They use their distinctive arrow-shaped crests to communicate and warn other members of their herd of danger.
_FirstCapture: Small, common plains dwellers with arrow-like crests they use to coordinate with others in their pack.
_Memo: Plains dwellers that move in packs. They use their arrow-like crests to coordinate movements and alert each other to threats. Since they stand their crests up when people and monsters draw near, that gesture is believed to indicate danger. Windrustlers have been sighted in Kunafa, a sign that they have learned two things: people aren't always a threat...and where there's people, there's food.

_FirstCapture: A rare variant occasionally spotted in a Windrustler pack. Distinguishable by their charcoal skin and larger frame.
_Memo: A rare variant occasionally spotted in a Windrustler pack, with charcoal skin and a larger frame. While it could be a type of melanistic mutation, there are enough unique examples to suggest this might even be a subspecies. Their role in the pack and relationship with others of their kind are important topics that warrant further study.

_FirstCapture: Birds that live in symbiosis with the Ceratonoth. They pick away old scales and feed on insects in between the cracks.
_Memo: Birds that live in symbiosis with the Ceratonoths and are often seen perched on their backs. They use their plier-like beaks to pick away old scales and feed on insects that have wormed their way into the cracks. In return for this grooming service, the Ceratonoths give the Nothpeckers a place to feed and shelter from outside threats— a win-win situation for all creatures involved.

_EnemyExp: A decomposer that breaks down the Fulgurite in its body consumed in order to eat the attached microbes. The Fulgurite makes its carapace shine.
_FirstCapture: Crustaceans that use their secretions to break down fulgurite and feed on the organic matter and microbes found within.
_Memo: Shrimp-like creatures that use their secretions to comb through fulgurite and feed on organic matter like dead Thunderbugs. The consumption of some of these microbes seems to have given the Landlight Shrimp a kind of luminescence. They use hook-like appendages to cling to rock faces in large numbers, happily eating away at the fulgurite and occasionally triggering falling boulders.

_FirstCapture: A land-dwelling crustacean that gathers on gaseous vents. Comes in a variety of sizes.
_Memo: Land-dwelling crustaceans that gather on gaseous vents in the Oilwell Basin. The hair on their heads and chests collects particles from the gas and steam, which attract the microbes that they feed on. The faint light they produce is thought to be a byproduct of the microbes they eat. They appear in a variety of sizes during the Firespring.

_EnemyExp: A migratory bird that flocks to the savannah during the bounty season to raise its young. It makes its nest largely from the bubbles it produces internally.
_FirstCapture: Migrant birds that live in the forest, but travel to the plains during the Plenty. Known for their foam nests and birdsong.
_Memo: Migrant birds that live in the forest, but travel to the plains during the Plenty to raise their young. Amstrigians choose lifelong mates and share the work when it comes to gathering food, building nests, and minding their young. Their meal of choice is insects, particularly Emperor Hoppers. They use their syrinxes to sing in chorus at the turning of the season, a social ritual that doubles as a form of communication.

_FirstCapture: A bird with a beautiful voice. It's very similar to the Amstrigian and can be seen mixed in with their flocks.
_Memo: Rare birds with beautiful voices. Though similar to the Amstrigian, their stunning songs and colorful feathers distinguish them. Not much is known about them due to their rarity.

_EnemyExp: A lizard that stores nutrients in a handkerchief-like sac. During the bounty season, it becomes predatorily active and its body takes on a red color.
_FirstCapture: Plateau-dwelling lizards with adipose tissue near their jaws that differ depending on their nutritional intake.
_Memo: Lizards with adipose tissue near their jaws and tail. When food is plentiful, these sac-like reservoirs fatten up and turn a healthy red. A Rufflizard with plenty of food in the tank is a happy Rufflizard, and you may see them basking in the sun and bobbing to each other in greeting. A poorly fed Rufflizard however, will move as little as possible.

_FirstCapture: A lizard with a distinctive crease on its head. It loves hot environments and is often seen in volcanic areas.
_Memo: Lizards with distinctive creases on their heads. When they bob their heads to communicate, the crease opens and glows along with the pattern on their bodies. They prefer hot environments such as volcanic areas. Though rarely seen in the oilsilt- filled upper areas of the Oilwell Basin, they become far more active during the Firespring. It's theorized that they primarily feed on bugs that lurk among the rocks.

_FirstCapture: An Ember Rufflizard peculiarly clad in blue and yellow.
_Memo: Rare lizards with a different coloration than the more common Ember Rufflizard. Since they so closely resemble the common Ember Rufflizard in every other way, they are currently thought to be a mere color variant as opposed to a subspecies. However, many reports claim these lizards are far larger, so they may be in the process of evolving into their own subspecies, a current hot topic among researchers.

_EnemyExp: A decomposer that eats dead monster carcasses. It holds food with its hair-covered ambulatory legs.
_FirstCapture: Insects that gather on carrion and feed on the dead flesh. Their foreleg bristles help them sweep food into their mouths.
_Memo: Insects that feed on dead flesh and serve as decomposers in the ecosystem. They use the bristles on their forelegs and joints to sweep organic matter from the carrion. When they're not feeding on dead monsters, they can usually be found lurking in between rocks or other places the sun doesn't reach.

_EnemyExp: An animal distinctive for the monogamous pairing it forms with another individual of its species. It can use its large tail to stand itself up and warn others.
_FirstCapture: Creatures with unusual tails that are native to the sands. They typically travel in pairs.
_Memo: Endemic creatures that are native to the Windward Plains—particularly its deserts. Thanks to their unusual tails, they can sit upright and assess their surroundings, or they can shield themselves from the hot sun. When they sit, their tails leave a mark in the sand that resembles a large monster's footprint. They typically travel in pairs to watch each other's back while doing things like drinking.

_EnemyExp: A grasshopper as big as its moniker would suggest. Its swift, frenetic jumps make it hard to capture.
_FirstCapture: Huge grasshoppers worthy of their name. Their powerful hind legs allow them to jump away, making them difficult to catch.
_Memo: Huge grasshoppers that have fully earned their name. Their powerful hind legs allow them to jump long distances and escape in a pinch. If you rustle through the grass—their usual hiding spot—you're bound to see at least one Emperor Hopper spring away. Grass fires throw them into a panic, a situation that certain other hungry creatures might be eager to take advantage of.

_FirstCapture: A puzzling phase mutation of the Emperor Hopper. Their bodies have a reddish-black discoloration, and are way more ferocious.
_Memo: A phase mutation of the Emperor Hopper. Their bodies are reddish-black and are more ferocious. While Hoppers are usually herbivorous, this type feeds on carrion. Due to similarities across different regions, it is believed the mutation must occur in environments where plants are scarce. This causal relationship between a creature's formative environment and its mutations has become a major subject of research.

_EnemyExp: A large beetle with impressive horns. Hercudrome only inhabit seven specific spots in the Windward Plains.
_FirstCapture: Beetles with distinct horns extending from the head and pronotum. They feed mainly on sap, and can often be found resting on tree trunks.
_Memo: Beetles with distinct horns extending from the head and pronotum. They are nocturnal and feed mainly on sap, which you can see if you observe tree trunks at night. The horns are used to compete for this food. They have wings, but their large size and heavy shells limit their flight capability. Since they buzz loudly while flying, you'll have an easier time finding them if you keep your ears open.

_FirstCapture: A Hercudrome subspecies with a shiny, golden carapace. While they share their ecology with the base species, these are significantly more rare.
_Memo: A Hercudrome subspecies with a shiny, golden carapace. Very few of these have been found, and no one has figured out why the carapaces are gold. However, the sightings span several regions and these are classified as a subspecies, not just a color variation. Because of their beauty, they are in high demand among collectors.

_FirstCapture: A member of the Hercudrome family with an iridescent carapace. The few confirmed sightings were in certain times or seasons.
_Memo: A member of the Hercudrome family with an iridescent carapace. Its pronotum is large and developed, with three prominent horns. Unlike ordinary Hercudromes, these inhabit the Ruins of Wyveria. Alas, there have been precious few sightings. Most have been at dawn or dusk, so that might be the best time to attempt and capture one.

_EnemyExp: Delicate insects that choose habitats that monsters won't approach, making them good indicators of where to set up a Pop-up Camp.
_FirstCapture: Delicate insects that can be found in nearly any climate. They choose habitats that monsters are unlikely to approach.
_Memo: Flying insects that resemble four-leaf clovers. Resilient to any weather, they can be found day or night in nearly any climate at places where monsters aren't likely to prowl. Which is a good indicator that an area is safe enough for a Pop-up Camp.

_FirstCapture: Butterflies that emerge at the start of the Plenty in large numbers, making them a crucial part of the ecosystem.
_Memo: Butterflies that hatch during the Plenty and pupate near its close. Those that survive the harsh Fallow emerge during the following season of Plenty. They adapt their life cycle to the Scarlet Forest, so if a population hatches early, it may reach adulthood within the same season. They feed a variety of predatory organisms, including insectivorous plants, making them a crucial part of the ecosystem.

_FirstCapture: Brightly colored beetles with impressive shells that fan outward. They gather on the trunks of trees in order to collect sap.
_Memo: Brightly colored beetles with impressive shells that fan outward. Each beetle's coloring and shapes are different—and with their sparkle, it's no wonder they're likened to gems. They tend to be diurnal, gathering on the trunks of trees in hopes of getting a nip of sap.

_FirstCapture: Jewel Scarabs with larger, more developed shells. The vast differences from specimen to specimen make them difficult to categorize.
_Memo: The finest of Jewel Scarab specimens, with larger, more developed shells. They are found with the rest of their kind, feeding on sap, but are near impossible to spot. While Jewel Scarabs are known for variations in shape and color, the Regal variants are a bit harder to explain. Are they the result of a particular larval diet? An acquired mutation? Are they even the same species at all? Only more research will tell.

_FirstCapture: Master weavers that ensnare prey using human-sized webs, but with an escape route in case predators approach.
_Memo: Master weavers that use webs to ensnare prey. You will often see butterflies and other insects caught in their webs, which is as big as a person and is equipped with an escape route for the Vaporonid in case predators approach. The silk used in the web is extremely sturdy and comes in handy if you need to make pitfall traps to ensnare a few monsters of your own.

_FirstCapture: Insects whose bellies glow yellow or red when they detect threats. They inhabit areas with abundant vegetation.
_Memo: Insects whose bellies glow yellow or red when they detect threats. Their resemblance to fossils seems to suggest that Omenflies have been around for quite a long time. The glowing seems to be a warning to enemies. Since Omenflies stay near the water, it is believed they keep their larvae in the water or in the moist soil nearby. Adults will stay airborne for the majority of their lives.

_FirstCapture: Forest creatures that survive by disguising themselves as plants. They can change disguises to adapt to environmental changes.
_Memo: Forest creatures that survive by using mimicry to disguise themselves as plants, confusing predators and luring in prey. Mimiphyta change form in response to seasonal and environmental changes; during the Fallow, they'll snuggle up at the base of a tree to live as fungi, while in the season of Plenty they blossom into lovely flowers and prey on butterflies and insects that flutter near.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that live in cold climates, often in abandoned buildings. They watch passers-by curiously while standing on their tails.
_Memo: Creatures that live in cold climates, often in abandoned buildings. Their slowness and lack of defensive measures suggest they aren't accustomed to threats. Perhaps because of this, they're not very cautious and will watch curiously while standing on their tails. They also like to gnaw on hard things like the Landspine to wear down their teeth. They are omnivorous today, but it's possible they fed on harder substances in the past.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that have adapted to living both on land and in the water. At night, they light up their luminous organs and cry out.
_Memo: Creatures that have adapted to living both on land and in the water. They are precious evidence of how amphibious creatures might have come to walk the earth. Scarlet Joyperch become active at night, when they light up the luminous organs near their heads, spread their fins, and let out a cry— presumably their way of strutting their stuff to other members of their kind.

_FirstCapture: An aquatic creature that has adapted to life on land. It attracts prey with the light on its head.
_Memo: Aquatic creatures that have adapted to life on land. Though similar to the Andangler, the shape of the light on their heads are different and are designed to attract the Sparklerjelly that float in the air of the Oilwell Basin. Due to this, some theorize that the Andangler and Blink Angler may have evolved from other amphibious fish.

_FirstCapture: A nocturnal creature that piles plants on its cup-like carapace and burrows into the ground to hide.
_Memo: Crabs that pile plants on their cup-like carapaces and burrow into the ground to hide from predators. Their claws are shaped like shovels, allowing them to burrow more easily. They generally remain buried during the day, becoming active only at night, where they can be found digging for insects to eat.

_FirstCapture: A nocturnal creature that piles plants on its cup-like carapace and burrows into the ground to hide.
_Memo: Crabs that pile oilsilt on their cup-like carapaces and burrow into the ground to hide from predators. Because oilsilt itself changes appearance depending on the season, it's theorized that these crabs must replace their silt to match. They are rarely seen in volcanic regions or during the Firespring, suggesting that they aren't particularly resistant to heat.

_FirstCapture: A Florashell Crab that has retained its ancient appearance. It flees at full speed the instant it spots a foe.
_Memo: Crabs that have retained their ancient appearance and are bigger than their standard brethren. They flee at full speed the instant they spot a foe, not bothering to camouflage themselves. Instead, they heap metal objects onto their carapaces, which are thought to be artifacts from ancient civilizations.

_FirstCapture: Lizards with luminous organs. When attacked, they drop luminous material as a decoy while they make a quick getaway.
_Memo: Lizards with luminous organs around their body. When attacked, they go dark and leave luminous material in their wake as a decoy while they make a quick getaway. From this observation, it can be surmised that it's not their epidermis that glows, but some other substance stored in their bodies. In line with these habits, Smokeshroud Gekkos can generally be found in dark, gloomy places.

_FirstCapture: Lizards that prefer deep caves and other places that light doesn't easily reach. They can live in even the harshest of climes.
_Memo: Lizards that prefer deep caves and other places that light doesn't easily reach. They can even survive in volcanic habitats, proof of their resilience in even the harshest of climes. Their toxicity is unknown, but the red and purple coloring of their skin is believed to be a warning. They survive by feeding on cave insects.

_FirstCapture: A species noted for its males who grow spectacularly colorful plumage after their molt to court females.
_Memo: A species noted for its males, who don spectacularly colorful plumage after molting. During the Fallow, their plumage is a subdued green to match the vegetation, but once the Plenty arrives, males preen to the nines, adopting a vibrant color palette— presumably to court females, since the more flamboyant males with larger feathers seem to be the ones flapping away with a date.

_FirstCapture: Male Dapperwings with bigger tails, brighter plumage, and some pretty good odds when it comes to courting the females.
_Memo: Male Dapperwings with bigger tails, brighter plumage, and some pretty darn good odds when it comes to courting the females. Not only that, it is believed the plumage the males achieve after molting plays a vital role in what traits they pass on to their offspring.

_FirstCapture: Nocturnal creatures that live in the desert. They are extremely wary and use acute hearing to detect and flee from threats.
_Memo: Nocturnal desert creatures with pale, luminescent fur that is believed to be the result of the insects they primarily feed on. Highly vigilant, they use their excellent hearing to detect approaching threats and flee, so trying to chase one down is the wrong approach. You'll have a far easier time catching one if you use a sonic bomb to disrupt its hearing.

_FirstCapture: A creature that is thought to have originally been a wyvern but evolved to live in caves like a bat.
_Memo: Creatures that greatly resemble bats. They hang from the ceiling in dark places like caves, and become active at night, preying on insects and smaller flying creatures. They can also be found in forests. Because of characteristics like their scales, it is theorized that they may have evolved from wyverns. Huge colonies live in caves in the Oilwell Basin, as evidenced by the piles of dung found there.

_FirstCapture: A jellyfish that floats in the air, preying upon airborne microbes.
_Memo: Jellyfish that float in the air. Often seen around the Coral Highlands in the New World. Environments that contain the airborne microbes they feed on and the air currents they use to get around are quite rare. Because the yellow ones found in the Oilwell Basin are all male and the larger, more colorful Peony Sparklerjelly are all female, it is theorized that they actually belong to the same species.

_FirstCapture: A larger, rarer jellyfish that floats in the air.
_Memo: Jellyfish that float in the air. They are larger and more colorful than their yellow brethren. The tiny beads of light within them are actually eggs and larvae, so it's believed that these creatures are entirely female. This suggests that they belong to the same species as the yellow Sparklerjelly, which are entirely male. That being said, it's exceptionally rare for jellyfish to have such extreme differences between sexes.

_FirstCapture: The larva of a Nu Udra. Can be found floating in the area at certain times.
_Memo: The larva of a Nu Udra. Though a fully grown Nu Udra hadn't been seen in a long time, there have been glimpses of this larval form. Not much is known about their breeding cycles, but it seems many eggs will hatch at once, meaning groups of the creature are not uncommon. The distinctive pattern on their heads appears to hide an underdeveloped eyeball and seems to grow into better support of the eye.

_FirstCapture: Xu Wu larvae. Their skin is transparent, and features a pattern unique to each specimen.
_Memo: Xu Wu larvae, newly hatched from their eggs. They already give off a faint luminescence, and patterns can be seen through their thin, transparent skin. They generally move in groups, but not in an organized manner— it's only because they hatched at the same time. After hatching, the nutrients from their eggs sustain them for a while. Beyond that, their diet remains unknown.

_FirstCapture: Creatures with fins that help them move through the air. They're delicate but have tremendous regenerative capabilities.
_Memo: Creatures with rippling fins on both sides of their body that help them move through the air. The fins possess a sort of circulatory system, similar to blood vessels, that give off light. Because their bodies are so fragile, even the slightest shock or gust of wind can tear them apart. Their regenerative abilities make up for this, however, as each piece becomes a separate individual.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that survive by attaching to the Wyrmway, using energy-receptive organs along their abdomens to harvest its energy.
_Memo: Creatures that survive by attaching to the Wyrmway, using energy-receptive organs along their abdomens to harvest its energy. This specialized adaptation, and its other traits that are consistent with ancient organisms, makes this species a fascinating subject of study. For example, their vision and nervous systems are highly developed for such a simple body structure, a detail that invites further investigation.

_FirstCapture: A special type of Pillopod with a larger body and prominent, expanded energy circulation system.
_Memo: A special type of Pillopod with a larger body and prominent, expanded energy circulation system. Their eyes are compressed, suggesting a mutation caused by excessive energy intake. However, considering how little is known about ordinary Pillopods, these mysteries may take some time to elucidate.

_FirstCapture: Insects found in abundance in the Ruins of Wyveria. While they are poor fliers, they use the wind to get around.
_Memo: Insects found in areas with ample vegetation such as the heart of the Ruins of Wyveria. Petalflies have poor flight capabilities, but they can still use the wind to get around. The larvae live in water or on moist ground until they mature, while an adult's short life span is spent reproducing. It has been suggested that the flowery fragrance the Petalflies give off may be a pheromone linked to mating.

_FirstCapture: Birds that can be sighted riding on the backs of small monsters. They are extremely wary of threats and are quick to flee,
_Memo: Birds that can be sighted riding on the backs of small monsters. They are extremely wary of external threats and are quick to flee, making them difficult to capture. Their disproportionately long legs allow them to move at high speeds. Populations have been observed living in some human settlements, allowing their eggs to be gathered in an extremely unusual symbiotic relationship.

_EnemyExp: A small fish that moves in large schools. It is common in bodies of water of the Windward Plains and the Forest. Notable for its bright, reflective blue and gold scales.
_FirstCapture: A small fish that is common prey for many creatures and prefers to live in schools. The schools can become impressively large.
_Memo: Small fish with blue and yellow scales that prefer to live in schools. The sizes of these schools vary and at times can become impressively large. Because they both breed rapidly and exist in large numbers, they are frequently preyed upon, making them the backbone of the ecosystem. Splashes on the surface of bodies of water are a sign of this fish fleeing from large predators.

_EnemyExp: A fish whose physiology remains almost unchanged from its ancient ancestors. Its spiny fins help ward off predators.
_FirstCapture: A species endemic to the Eastlands. They are more common in warm areas and are noted for their bright green bodies.
_Memo: A species endemic to the Eastlands. They are more common in warm areas, suggesting that they have adapted to more temperate climates. Compared to other fish, Virid Bowfins are neither particularly useful nor suitable for eating, so anglers tend to treat them as bycatch. On the other hand, they have high scientific value because they exhibit unique traits not seen outside their Eastland habitat.

_EnemyExp: A fish with a dorsal fin hard enough to be used to sharpen weapons.
_FirstCapture: Fish with scales and fins hard enough to surpass common whetstones. The fins in particular are frequently used for sharpening.
_Memo: Fish covered with scales and fins of considerable durability. In fact, Whetfish are so hard that they are often used in place of common whetstones to sharpen weapons. It is believed these hardened features evolved as a defense mechanism against predators. They show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_EnemyExp: Sushifish are a popular hunter staple. Their nutrient-rich scales can also be used to restore health.
_FirstCapture: A popular food source high in nutrition. Their scales are capable of restoring health.
_Memo: A popular food source found in many a hunter's pouch, these fish have very high nutritional value—not just in their flesh, but their scales too. They offer a remarkable range of benefits, including health and bleeding recovery, and stamina boosts. Because of this, Sushifish are common prey for many aquatic species. They show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Large fish with a habit of gobbling up everything they see—including a hunter's tools.
_Memo: Large fish that gobble up anything and everything they can swallow, including things a hunter might use for tools. Gastronome Tuna are commonly observed during the season of Plenty, when smaller fish are abundant. Food is scarce during the Fallow, however, so sightings become rare as they move to more fruitful feeding grounds. They show a strong interest in Tuff Joint Bait.

_FirstCapture: Fish with flat heads, broad mouths, and long whiskers. They are known to grow to a considerable size.
_Memo: Large fish with flat heads, broad mouths, and long whiskers. They are known to grow to a considerable size—some as large as a human. While an Eastland Gajau is wary and will flee from a perceived threat, there have been documented Gajau attacks in other parts of the world. Researchers link such differences in behavior to habitat. Gajau show a strong interest in Duster Rigs.

_FirstCapture: Sparkly fish often found in slow currents. They are in high demand for aquariums, and their scales fetch a pretty zenny, too.
_Memo: Due to their sparkly appearance, Goldenfry are in high demand as aquarium fish, and their scales fetch a pretty zenny as well. Their distinctive traits—the short body, the long, broad fins—are not commonly seen in nature, leading some researchers to believe an anthropogenic factor might be at play. Goldenfry show a strong interest in Golden Bugheads.

_FirstCapture: Fish with stunning golden scales covering their bodies. Their scales fetch high prices as accessory materials.
_Memo: With the stunning golden scales covering their bodies, it's no wonder these fish are aquarium staples and often sell for high prices for use in accessories. Goldenfish can be found in caves and other places with no sunlight and calm waters. Conversely, you will rarely see them out in the sun or in swift currents. They show a strong interest in Golden Bugheads.

_FirstCapture: Fish covered with platinum-colored scales. Some theorize they are related to Goldenfish due to their similar appearance and habits.
_Memo: Fish covered with platinum-colored scales. Like the Goldenfish, they are a popular feature in aquariums and accessories—but at higher prices, because of their relative scarcity. The leading theory for the Platinumfish's unique coloring is that they adapted to their sunless cave environments. They show a strong interest in Golden Bugheads.

_FirstCapture: Fish that possess scales with explosive properties. Useful for crafting items like bowgun ammo.
_Memo: Fish with scales that detonate, a property that allows them to be crafted into things like bowgun ammo. How the Burst Arowana came to be this way is an unsolved mystery, and the debate rages on; some theorize it was an inherent trait, others that it was acquired through feeding habits. Burst Arowana show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Fish with scales that trigger a powerful explosion, making them great material for potent bowgun ammo.
_Memo: Fish with scales that detonate even more powerfully than the Burst Arowana's, making them great material for potent bowgun ammo. The Burst and Bomb Arowana's relationship is disputed. Is the latter a subspecies? Should the difference be chalked up to habitat? Researchers are confident that this line of questioning will eventually reveal the fishes' explosive secrets. Bomb Arowanas show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Fish that have large, protruding eyes on either side of their heads and explosive scales that are useful in bomb-making.
_Memo: Fish that have explosive scales useful in bomb-making. The large, protruding eyes they have on both sides are rarely seen in nature, prompting some to theorize that the species evolved through human manipulation, only to become wild sometime later. Gunpowderfish show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Large fish characterized by the long rostra extending from their heads. Seen often during Fallows, but absent during Plenties.
_Memo: Large fish characterized by the long rostra extending from their heads. The rostra are used to catch prey and defend against enemies. Speartuna are a common sight during the Fallow, but absent during the Plenty. It is believed that they avoid competing with other large fish over the abundant food. Speartuna show a strong interest in Tuff Joint Bait.

_FirstCapture: So few of these fish have been found alive that they were once thought to be extinct. They retain the same form as in ancient times.
_Memo: So few of these fish have been found alive that they were once thought to be extinct. At one point, they only turned up as fossils —and in a way, they <ITALIC>are</ITALIC> living fossils since they retain the same form as in ancient times. Research on the ecology of the Petricanths might just elucidate how other prehistoric organisms lived. Petricanths show a strong interest in Duster Rigs.

_FirstCapture: Fish with transparent bodies, a protective measure to conceal themselves from predators. They prefer colder habitats.
_Memo: Fish with transparent bodies that reveal their bones and organs. This protective coloration—or lack thereof, rather—hides them from predators. Glass Parexus prefer colder regions, and are often found in clear waters where their transparency is most effective.

_FirstCapture: Huge nocturnal aquatic creatures with long tentacles. Their bodies glow as they swim around at night.
_Memo: Huge nocturnal creatures that have eight short legs, two long tentacles, and distinctive patterning on their bodies. Goliath Squids use special luminescent organs to light up their whole body, scaring off enemies and hunting prey. Some believe it might also be a way for them to communicate with each other. They show a strong interest in Tentacle Jigs.

_FirstCapture: Large fish notable for their sizeable mouths, which can gobble down large prey in one gulp.
_Memo: Large fish notable for their sizeable mouths, which can gobble down most small- to medium- sized prey in one go. Great Trevally are diurnal and have a wide range of habitats. Smaller specimens can even be found in the shallows. They show a strong interest in Tuff Joint Bait.

_FirstCapture: Creatures with exceptionally hard shells that keep the majority of their bodies hidden from predators.
_Memo: Creatures with exceptionally hard shells that keep the majority of their bodies hidden from predators. Their numerous tentacles draw in and catch prey. Escunites move by expelling water from organs called siphons that are hidden inside their tentacles. They show a strong interest in Tentacle Jigs.

_FirstCapture: Escunite specimens with blanched bodies. Compared to normal Escunites, precious few have been discovered thus far.
_Memo: Escunite specimens with blanched bodies. Every part—shell, tentacles, and all—is white. Several theories have been put forward as to why this happens: a mutation, or a defensive measure to better blend into surroundings. However, until more specimens are collected and research conducted, it will remain as speculation. Grand Escunites show a strong interest in Tentacle Jigs.

_FirstCapture: Fish with head plating to defend against threats. The roe in their abdomens is safe for consumption and highly nutritious.
_Memo: Fish with head plating to defend against threats. The plating is not part of their biology but rather a collection of scavenged materials. Because of the similar fin shapes, some believe these are actually female Virid Bowfins in their breeding period. However, not enough specimens have been found or studied to shed light on these theories. Gravid Bowfins show a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Fish that have adapted to waters where Wyvern Milk flows. Their eyes have degenerated to reduce energy consumption.
_Memo: Fish that have adapted to waters where Wyvern Milk flows. Their eyes have degenerated, presumably to reduce energy consumption. In lieu of sight, Blind Perch have developed organs on the sides of their bodies to sense tremors in the water and gain awareness of their surroundings. What they use for nourishment still remains unknown.
